text: Why does the semicolon collect the range in x = [1:5;]? This results in [1,2] == [1;2] but [1:5,6:10] != [1:5;6:10]. Found in an example in the doc about dot functions

elements.text: Why does the semicolon collect the range in x = [1:5;]? This results in [1,2] == [1;2] but [1:5,6:10] != [1:5;6:10]. Found in an example in the doc about dot functions

text:
```julia> Meta.@lower [1:2;3:4]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = 1:2
│   %2 = 3:4
│   %3 = Base.vcat(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

julia> Meta.@lower [1:2, 3:4]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = 1:2
│   %2 = 3:4
│   %3 = Base.vect(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))```

elements.text:
julia> Meta.@lower [1:2;3:4]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = 1:2
│   %2 = 3:4
│   %3 = Base.vcat(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

julia> Meta.@lower [1:2, 3:4]
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = 1:2
│   %2 = 3:4
│   %3 = Base.vect(%1, %2)
└──      return %3
))))

text: thx. Well then the question changes to why cat/vect behaves differently, but judging from source, I guess the answer is they were just written so ... Anyway, good to keep in mind that ; is internally not cat()
